abstract.p: Brian O'Meara letter criticizes US unwillingness to agree to permament war crimes tribunal that would have power over Americans

block.p: Re ''U.S. Gains a Compromise on War Crimes Tribunal'' (news article, June 30):

The worsening isolationist streak in American politics poses a threat to world security. First, the United States opposed an international criminal court, preferring underfinanced ad hoc tribunals, a move that, as we have seen, results in only spotty prosecution.
Re ''U.S. Gains a Compromise on War Crimes Tribunal'' (news article, June 30):

The worsening isolationist streak in American politics poses a threat to world security. First, the United States opposed an international criminal court, preferring underfinanced ad hoc tribunals, a move that, as we have seen, results in only spotty prosecution.
Now the United States is trying to establish a precedent for granting all people from a country (Americans, in this case) blanket immunity from prosecution by the court.

If this precedent goes through, countries ruled by people who do commit grave crimes against humanity will seek similar loopholes, destroying the effectiveness of the court as a prosecutor of crime and a deterrent against it.
It's time for the United States to take responsibility as a member of the world community.
